Legal_Issue: Whether 'Glen Breton' is deceptively misdescriptive under the Trade-marks Act
Legal_Provision: Sections 10 and 12(1)(e) of the Trade-marks Act
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 12(1)(e) – Prohibition on deceptively misdescriptive marks
Legal_Rule: Marks that are deceptively misdescriptive or have become recognized by ordinary and bona fide commercial usage as designating a specific origin are not registrable
Applicable_Process: Administrative opposition proceeding before the Trademarks Office, followed by appeal to Federal Court
Applicant_Challenge: Glenora Distillers' application for 'Glen Breton' trademark
Grounds_for_Claim: Likelihood of consumer confusion due to association of 'Glen' with Scottish whisky
Evidence_Assessment: No Canadian whisky with 'Glen' in name existed before 2000; 'Glen' strongly associated with Scottish whisky
Key_Evidence_Considered: Consumer perception evidence, historical usage of 'Glen' in whisky branding
Evidence_Type: Commercial usage data, consumer confusion studies
Credibility_Factor: Evidence demonstrated established association between 'Glen' and Scotch whisky
Burden_of_Proof: On opponent (Scotch Whisky Association) to show ineligibility for registration
Defendant_Response: Glenora argued for distinctiveness of 'Glen Breton' as a Canadian brand
Procedural_Issue: Admissibility of new evidence on appeal
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: New evidence was properly considered on appeal
Remedy_Sought: Prevent registration of 'Glen Breton' to protect geographical indication
